jcr:content.jcr:title: Meet Saudi
jcr:content.jcr:description: From how to get here, to navigating the currency, climate and culture once you’ve arrived, here’s everything you need to know about visiting Saudi Arabia.
jcr:content.pageTitle: Useful Information - Visit Saudi Official Website

c02_title_intro.introDescription: From how to get here, to navigating the currency, climate and culture once you’ve arrived, here’s everything you need to know about visiting Saudi Arabia.

item3.copy: THINGS TO DO IN THE KINGDOM

item_1.jcr:title: Tab 1
item_1.description: Arabic is the official language of Saudi Arabia and the primary language used in all dealings and public transactions. Saudi Arabia’s rich heritage and traditions have been shaped by its position as a historic trade hub and the birthplace of Islam.
item_1.title: Language and Culture

item_2.jcr:title: Tab 2
item_2.description: Public etiquette in Saudi Arabia is informed by our cultural heritage and Islamic religion, and underpinned by values that are familiar to people everywhere: respect for others, decorum in public and protection of privacy.
item_2.title: Laws and Etiquette

item_1574269002456.description: Contrary to popular belief, Saudi Arabia has four distinct seasons and a climate that varies between regions. Read on for a seasonal overview of the Kingdom’s weather.
item_1574269002456.title: Climate and Seasons

item_1.jcr:title: Tab 1
item_1.description: With 13 international airports, served by a wealth of international carriers, getting to and around the Kingdom couldn’t be easier.
item_1.title: Getting Here

item_2.jcr:title: Tab 2
item_2.description: A first-rate transportation system connects Saudi Arabia’s provinces and cities, serving millions of people each day.
item_2.title: Getting Around

item_1574269618241.description: Saudi Arabia’s national currency is the Saudi riyal (ر.س SAR), which is subdivided into 100 halala. You’ll receive notes in denominations of 5 riyals, 10 riyals, 50 riyals, 100 riyals and 500 riyals; and coins in 1 riyal, 2 riyals, 50 halala, 25 halala, 10 halala, 5 halala and 1 halala.
item_1574269618241.title: Currencies and Payments

c07_evisa.leftDescription: The simplest and quickest way to issue your visa to the Kingdom. Apply and receive it instantly in your inbox.
c07_evisa.rightDescription: The Saudi Arabian visa is accessible for all. We look forward to welcome and host you in the Kingdom.

c07_evisa.rightDescription: The Saudi Arabian visa is accessible to all. We look forward to welcoming and hosting you in the Kingdom.

jcr:content.jcr:title: Language and Culture
jcr:content.jcr:description: Find out about Saudi Arabia’s rich language, heritage and traditions.
jcr:content.pageTitle: Language and Culture - Visit Saudi Official Website

c03_card.description: Arabic is the official language of Saudi Arabia and the primary language used in all dealings and public transactions. English serves as an informal second language in the Kingdom and is spoken by a large section of its society. All road signs are bilingual, showing information in both Arabic and English.
c03_card.title: Language

c03_card_copy.description: Saudi Arabia’s rich heritage and traditions have been shaped by its position as a historic trade hub and the birthplace of Islam. In recent years, the Kingdom has undergone a significant cultural transformation, evolving century-old customs to fit the contemporary world we live in today.
c03_card_copy.title: Culture

jcr:content.jcr:title: Laws and Etiquette
jcr:content.jcr:description: Public etiquette in Saudi Arabia is informed by our cultural heritage and Islamic religion, and underpinned by values that are familiar to people everywhere.
jcr:content.pageTitle: Laws and Etiquette - Visit Saudi Official Website

c02_title_intro.introDescription: Public etiquette in Saudi Arabia is informed by our cultural heritage and Islamic religion, and underpinned by values that are familiar to people everywhere: respect for others, decorum in public and protection of privacy.

c03_card.description: Both men and women are asked to dress modestly in public, avoiding tight-fitting clothing or clothes with profane language or images. Women should cover shoulders and knees in public.
c03_card.title: Dress

c98_footnote_1184826105.heading: Violations to public decency and penalties

c03_card.description: Public displays of affection are not consistent with local culture and visitors should also avoid using profane language or gestures.
c03_card.title: Public Behaviour

c98_footnote_1184826.heading: Violations to public decency and penalties

c03_card.description: At prayer time, five times a day, music is turned off in public places and many shops close briefly.  For one month a year, during Ramadan, Muslims fast from dawn to dusk and so it is respectful to avoid eating or drinking in public during the day at this time.
c03_card.title: Religion

c98_footnote.heading: Violations to public decency and penalties

c03_card.description: The sale, purchase and consumption of alcohol are illegal in Saudi Arabia. It is illegal to bring alcohol or drugs into the country.
c03_card.title: Alcohol and Substances

c98_footnote.heading: Violations to public decency and penalties

jcr:content.jcr:title: Getting Here
jcr:content.jcr:description: With 13 international airports, served by a wealth of international carriers, getting to and around the Kingdom couldn’t be easier.
jcr:content.pageTitle: Getting Here - Visit Saudi Official Website

jcr:content.jcr:title: Getting Around
jcr:content.jcr:description: A first-rate transportation system connects Saudi Arabia’s provinces and cities, serving millions of people each day.
jcr:content.pageTitle: Getting Around - Visit Saudi Official Website

item_1.jcr:title: Tab 1
item_1.description:
Hiring a car is an efficient and cost-effective way to explore Saudi Arabia and visit the country’s many tourist attractions. Cars can be rented at airports, or in most cities, making it easy to get out and explore.

*In the case of any issue or problem do not hesitate to call 938
item_1.title: Car Rentals

item_2.jcr:title: Tab 2
item_2.description:
Taxis in Saudi Arabia are easy to find, particularly around busy locations such as shopping malls, hypermarkets and public parks. All are equipped with a digital meter detailing the fare, together with information on the driver and operating company. Some hotels offer cars for private hire too.

*In the case of any issue or problem do not hesitate to call 938
item_2.title: Taxis

item_1574258748603.description:
A number of ride-hailing apps operate in the Kingdom, including Uber and Careem. Just tap in your pick-up and drop-off locations and track your driver’s arrival online. Payment can be made either by cash or credit card.

*In the case of any issue or problem do not hesitate to call 938
item_1574258748603.title: Use a Ride-hailing App

item_1574258770917.description:
Saudi’s railway system operates through three primary train stations:

Riyadh-Dammam connects Riyadh to the Eastern Region and passes through the following stations: Dammam, Abqaiq, Hofuf and Riyadh.
www.saudirailways.org

The North Train connects Riyadh to the north of Saudi Arabia and serves the following stations: Riyadh, Al Majmaah, Qassim, Ha’il and Al Jouf.
www.sar.com.sa

Haramain High-Speed Railway is the latest and fastest train in the Middle East, operating between the holy cities of Makkah and Madinah in western Saudi Arabia. It serves the following stations: Makkah, Jeddah, King Abdullah Economic City and Madinah.
www.hhr.sa
item_1574258770917.title: Trains

item_1574258871687.description:
The Saudi Public Transport Company (SAPTCO) operates a comprehensive network of bus services across the Kingdom, linking all major cities, towns and villages. For more information and to purchase tickets, please visit:

https://www.saptco.com.sa/Buses/Home.aspx
item_1574258871687.title: Buses

jcr:content.jcr:title: Climate and Seasons
jcr:content.jcr:description: Saudi Arabia has four distinct seasons and a climate that varies between regions. Read on for a seasonal overview of the Kingdom’s weather.
jcr:content.pageTitle: Climate and Seasons - Visit Saudi Official Website

c02_title_intro.introDescription: Contrary to popular belief, Saudi Arabia has four distinct seasons and a climate that varies between regions. Read on for a seasonal overview of the Kingdom’s weather.

item_1.jcr:title: Tab 1
item_1.description: Spring in Saudi Arabia can be brisk, particularly in the north, where the temperature at night can drop to below 15 degrees. The central and southern regions are warmer, averaging around 20 degrees after nightfall. Rainfall is at its highest now, particularly in the central region and in the southwest over the Asir Mountains.
item_1.title: Spring

item_2.jcr:title: Tab 2
item_2.description: Summer signals the start of rising temperatures across much of the country, with the exception of the comparatively mild highlands in the southwest. The early mornings and long evenings are more temperate with gentle winds, so take advantage of the warm seas to explore Saudi Arabia’s world-class dive sites, or try your hand at other watersports.
item_2.title: Summer

item_1574259616964.description: Autumn brings gentler weather and cool breezes in both Saudi Arabia’s northern regions and the southwestern highlands. While daytime temperatures remain warm, evenings are mild and perfect for outdoor strolling along Jeddah’s waterfront, indulging in al-fresco dining, or visiting Al Ahsa’s cool desert springs.
item_1574259616964.title: Autumn

item_1574259624330.description: Take advantage of Saudi Arabia’s beautiful winter weather to explore the Kingdom. The balmy days and cool nights are perfect for camping, rock climbing, or just exploring Saudi Arabia’s bustling cities and verdant highlands. You might even be lucky enough to see snowfall in the mountains of the northern regions, blanketing the slopes and desert sands.
item_1574259624330.title: Winter

jcr:content.jcr:title: Currencies and Payments
jcr:content.jcr:description: Currency exchange and transactions are easy in Saudi Arabia. Its national currency is the Saudi riyal (ر.س SAR), which is subdivided into 100 halala.
jcr:content.pageTitle: Currencies and Payments - Visit Saudi Official Website

c02_title_intro.introDescription: Currency exchange and transactions are easy in Saudi Arabia.

c03_card.description:
Saudi Arabia’s national currency is the Saudi riyal (ر.س SAR), which is subdivided into 100 halala.

You’ll receive notes in denominations of five riyals, ten riyals, 50 riyals, 100 riyals and 500 riyals; and coins in one riyal, two riyals, 50 halala, 25 halala, 10 halala, five halala and one halala.
c03_card.title: Currency

c03_card_421433508.description: All banks in the Kingdom offer currency exchange services. Exchange bureaus are located at airports, some shopping centres and various other locations in the country. The US dollar is equivalent to SAR 3.75 (fixed rate). Credit cards, such as Visa, MasterCard and American Express are accepted throughout the Kingdom. ATMs are also widely available.
c03_card_421433508.title: Currency Exchange

c03_card_1648380055.description: You can send or receive money in Saudi Arabia by transferring funds online, or through a bank that offers fast money transfer services, all of which are subject to the rules and regulations of the Saudi Arabian Monetary Authority (SAMA).
c03_card_1648380055.title: Send and Receive Money

c03_card_778390067.description: Saudi Arabia imposes an indirect tax of 5% (VAT) on all goods and services purchased and sold by enterprises. There are some exceptions.
c03_card_778390067.title: Taxes

jcr:content.jcr:title: Useful Contacts
jcr:content.jcr:description: To guarantee a safe and hassle-free stay in Saudi, here are the country's most important emergency numbers, useful contacts and telephone codes.
jcr:content.pageTitle: Useful Contacts - Visit Saudi Official Website

item_1.jcr:title: Tab 1
item_1.description:
Police: 999
Saudi Ambulance: 997
Civil Defence: 998
For traffic accidents: 993
Highway Patrol: 996
Border Guard: 994
item_1.title: Emergency Numbers

item_2.jcr:title: Tab 2
item_2.description:
Tourism Call Center: 19988
Tourism International Call Center: 00966112614750
Najm Company: 920000560
Passports: 992
Saudi Public Security: 989
General enquiries: 905
Emergency medical consultation: 937
Municipalities: 940
Electricity company emergency: 933
Ministry of Transport emergency: 938
Enquiries related to Ministry of Commerce: 1900
Consumer protection: 935
General Directorate of Narcotics Control: 995
item_2.title: Useful Numbers

item_1574260400799.description:
Saudi Arabia’s country code is 00966 There are three mobile network providers in Saudi Arabia. These are:

STC
Mobily
Zain
item_1574260400799.title: Telephone Code and Providers
